  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
Today marks the first
  time since 1963 that the U.S.
  government has quarantined one of its citizens. The patient under quarantine
  – an unidentified Georgia
  man – is infected with a rare and dangerous form of tuberculosis, and
  may have exposed passengers and crew of two trans-Atlantic flights. Nancy
  Cordes will have the story and our Dr. Jon LaPook will tell you more about
  how tuberculosis could be having a dangerous comeback.
 
As we honored America’s
  fallen soldiers on Memorial Day, violence in Iraq
  killed at least 10 U.S.
  troops, making May the deadliest month for our soldiers in Iraq this
  year. Lara Logan will report on the recent violence and have an exclusive
  interview with Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki.
 
And attacks on U.S. forces could be on the rise by
  the end of summer. David Martin will have an update on the troop surge in Iraq
  and what that could mean for the violence there.
 
Meanwhile, extremely dry conditions are straining
  the Southeast United States – causing
  neighbors to turn in neighbors for violating water restrictions and prompting
  churchgoers to pray for rain. But what’s behind this suddenly severe
  drought? Kelly Cobiella will explain.
 
In certain parts of the Midwest,
  trees are pulsing with the rhythm of hundreds of thousands of cicadas. Chicago’s suburbs
  are in the midst of the reawakening of a certain brood of cicadas that only hatches
  once every 17 years. Michelle Miller is there, and will have the story of the
  moment these cicadas have been waiting for.
 
And tonight we’ll have a special report from
  correspondent Kimberly Dozier, who is making her return to the CBS Evening
  News by reporting on the new crop of Iraq war wounds and the suffering
  they’re causing patients. And later tonight, Dozier will be telling the
  story of the attack that hit her CBS News crew one year ago.
  “Flashpoint,” a one-hour special, will air tonight on CBS at 10
  p.m. ET/PT. Also, check out the special “Flashpoint”
  section at CBSNews.com.
 
I hope you had a great Memorial Day weekend.
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
